awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Coring in the Southwest Indian and Southern Oceans to examine climate driven changes in watermass paleoventilation, sources, and structure
awd_abstract_narration:
Fifty times more CO2 resides in the ocean than the atmosphere. Exchange of CO2 with the atmosphere and the storage of CO2 in the ocean is an important control on atmospheric concentrations. During recent ice ages, atmospheric CO2 concentrations were naturally 30% lower than pre industrial levels.  Extensive evidence indicates this reduction was caused by greater storage of CO2 in the ocean. Today, wind-driven air-sea exchange in the Southern Ocean is one of the primary mechanisms for CO2 exchange between these two reservoirs.  During the last glacial interval, reduced exchange in the Southern Ocean driven by changes in ocean circulation and the resulting changes in ocean chemistry is believed to have played an important role in sequestering more CO2 in the ocean; however, there is ongoing debate about the specific state of glacial oceanic and atmospheric circulation in the Southern Ocean. Current studies are hampered by a lack of suitable sediment cores from key locations; existing cores are concentrated in the South Atlantic and Southwestern Pacific. There are clearly changes in the chemistry and circulation of water masses between these two regions, but there is little information available from the critical region of the Southern Indian Ocean where much of the CO2 exchange occurs today. The few cores from this area that do exist have been exhausted over the past 30 years of research. In this study, researchers will collect cores on a cruise to Southeast Indian Ocean waters and conduct the initial shore-based stratigraphic and environmental analyses. Collaborations with Australian scientists will be an integral part of this work and these cores will be an important resource for scientists around the world. The project supports the training of both a graduate student and a postdoctoral researcher.

The circulation and ventilation of water masses at intermediate depths (~500-1400 m) in the Southern Indian Ocean are central to atmosphere-ocean CO2 partitioning. During glaciations changes in both thermohaline circulation and wind-driven Southern Ocean ventilation are believed to have played an important role in sequestering atmospheric CO2. A detailed understanding of the interaction between the physical mechanisms of thermohaline overturning circulation and wind-driven ventilation requires precise definition of changes in water mass boundaries and properties across the deglaciation. The use of vertical and horizontal transects of sediment core material has been fundamental in identifying past variations in the structure of the ocean. Published transects of paleo-proxies in the glacial South Atlantic differ substantially from the Southwest Pacific, leading to the idea that processes in the Southeast Indian Ocean had a significant influence on glacial CO2 exchange. Consequently, this work will constrain surface frontal locations that shift in response to changes in atmospheric circulation, as well as deep water mass boundaries and properties that vary with ocean circulation patterns. The cruise objective is to obtain 30-50 cores to create depth and latitudinal transects underlying both subantarctic and subtropical waters in the Southeast Indian Ocean from a region west and south of Australia. The scientific objective is to determine the temporal evolution of the horizontal and vertical distribution of proxies (e.g.13C, 18O, Nd isotopes) that will reconstruct the water source and ventilation history of this critical region of the Southern Ocean.  The scientific outcomes will be to produce: 1) the first depth transect of water mass proxies in the Indian Ocean sector of the Southern Ocean over the last glacial cycle, and 2) a latitudinal transect of surface and deep water properties.

por.por_cntn:
Fifty times more CO2 resides in the ocean than the atmosphere. Exchange of CO2 with the atmosphere and the storage of CO2 in the ocean is an important control on atmospheric concentrations. During recent ice ages, atmospheric CO2 concentrations were naturally 30% lower than pre industrial levels. Extensive evidence indicates this reduction was caused by greater storage of CO2 in the ocean. Today, wind-driven air-sea exchange in the Southern Ocean is one of the primary mechanisms for CO2 exchange between these two reservoirs.  During the last glacial interval, reduced exchange in the Southern Ocean driven by changes in ocean circulation and the resulting changes in ocean chemistry is believed to have played an important role in sequestering more CO2 in the ocean; however, there is ongoing debate about the specific state of glacial oceanic and atmospheric circulation in the Southern Ocean. Previous studies have largely concentrated in the South Atlantic and Southwestern Pacific. There are clearly changes in the chemistry and circulation of water masses between these two regions, but work here focused on the critical region of the Southern Indian Ocean where very few sediment cores were previously available.  

The coring expedition in 2018was very successful. The original objective was to obtain 40 new cores for paleo studies.  Sea going efforts obtained 36 sediment cores that were complimented by 20 hydro casts of water samples that were analyzed to determine the current levels of geochemical proxies for ground-truthing. These cores have provided key new material from previously unavailable locations and ocean depths. Work is still ongoing with additional funds to fill this knowledge gap.

Paleoceanographic reconstructions rely upon paleo-environmental proxies that preserve a record of the parameter in question.  The ratio of carbon isotopes within seawater was examined to identify and quantify atmospheric influences for the paleo studies and to compare to data from a decade ago. Published results from this study identified a significant amount of atmospheric carbon sourced from human activities, such as burning of biomass and fossil fuels, has been absorbed into the southeastern Indian Ocean over the last decade. Work supported by this funding showed that the rate at which this is being absorbed by the ocean has increased up to 3-fold over this time period, when compared with the period between 1994 and 2008.

 

An important component of utilizing new unstudied cores is establishing their stratigraphy, that is, converting depth-down core to an estimate of time using geochemical markers. Shore-based stratigraphic analyses determined a number of cores were suitable for detailed glacial-timescale paleoceanographic study. Determining that some cores had high enough resolution for this level of detail guided the choice of cores for initial work to address questions related to changes in deep ocean circulation and CO2 sequestration.

 

Two proxies 1) neodymium isotopes, which can be used to distinguish Atlantic- and Pacific- sourced waters, and 2) the distribution of grain sizes for silt in the sediment, which is referred to as sortable silt measurements, were analyzed to reconstruction the relative balance of North Atlantic versus Southern Hemisphere water that fills the Southern Ocean water and to track current speed over several glacial cycles. Published results using the combination of these lines of evidence demonstrated that there were reductions in North Atlantic-sourced waters and slower bottom water current speeds within the deep Southern Ocean during the last ice age. This confirms the reduced influence of waters from the ice-covered Northern Hemisphere during glacial advances in that region. The Northern versus Southern water dominance showed a tight coupling between ocean circulation changes, Antarctic climate, and atmospheric CO2 concentrations throughout the last 118,000 years and suggests a southern hemisphere control on paleo-circulation and influences on atmospheric CO2 through this time.

 

This work supported two post-docs and a PhD student. Sea going efforts during the coring cruise included collaborations with Australian and British scientists with significant Southern Ocean experience as an integral part of this work.  Shipboard participation included: 1) international participation from 2 Australian institutions, and 1 UK institution, 2) participation of 12 US scientists, 4 of whom were early career post-docs, and 5 students, 3) outreach activity through a shipboard blog, and 4) two official piggy back projects that were funded by NSF to take advantage of the strategic location of this scientific voyage.
